Award.AwardTitle: Bimodal Nanofiber Mats with Controlled Microstructures for Size-Sensitive Nanoparticle Filtration/Separation and Superhydrophobic Drag Reduction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to develop an innovative nano-manufacturing technique to create new porous materials with improved functionalities. These materials will consist of polymer nanofiber layers with bimodal diameters ranging from 50 to 1000 nanometers. The fiber diameters and orientation will be controlled to enhance specific material functionality and the design will be guided using advanced computational methods. The transformational functionality of these nanofibrous materials makes them attractive for applications such as nanoparticle filtration in comfortably-breathable, size-sensitive face masks and respirators, as well as high-efficiency industrial and residential air filters, and low-cost superhydrophobic self-cleaning surfaces. The project combines experimental nano-manufacturing of nanofiber materials and numerical simulations to design and optimize structural parameters such as fiber diameters, mass fraction of each component, and fiber orientations.

Successful completion of this research will lead to transformational advances towards manufacturing new porous materials with significantly enhanced performance. In particular, outcomes of this research will create new nano-manufacturing methodologies that can be used to produce a new class of engineered fibrous materials with minimum resistance, i.e., pressure drop, against fluid flows, leading to significant energy cost savings. The project will include participation from under-represented minority students and local high school students. A new technical elective undergraduate course entitled "Aerosols and In-door Air Engineering" will be offered to Mechanical and Chemical Engineering students at VCU.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project has been to investigate the possibility of using electrospun nanofiber materials for two distinct applications: 1) nanoparticle filtration/separation, and 2) drag force reduction on submerged surfaces. The specific objective of our work has been to design (virtually) and manufacture (experimentally) electrospun mats with fibers deposited orthogonally with respect to one another, and to predict and characterize the performance of the resulting mats. For the first application, our experimental results indicate that the most efficient aerosol filters, which are those with the highest particle collection efficiency for a given pressure drop, can be obtained through fabricating filters in orthogonal layers of aligned nanofibers possibly with different fiber diameters. We developed various computational algorithms for custom-designing the microstructure of such fibrous media for both the clean and particle-loaded operational conditions. For the second application, developed new methods to predict the performance of submerged superhydrophobic nanofiber coatings in terms of their underwater longevity and friction reduction benefit.

 

Several graduate and undergraduate students have been involved in research during the course of this investigation. These students gain valuable experience working in the areas of nanomanufacturing, fluid mechanics, and interfacial phenomena, and their findings have been disseminated through journal and conference publications. The fundamental science and the enabling knowledge that have been created during the course of this research is expected to be invaluable to industry in manufacturing nanofiber materials with superior performance in the above-mentioned areas of engineering. Advanced nanoparticle filters or superhydrophobic mats with controlled microstructure can be more efficient in removing harmful aerosols or providing a frictionless coating for submerged surfaces, and thereby may leave smaller carbon footprints as they operate.
